statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Arkansas 89, Delaware St. 67
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Darian Townes scored 18 points and Charles Thomas added 15 to lead Arkansas over Delaware State 89-67 Saturday. Stefan Welsh had 12 points and seven assists for the Razorbacks, who finally took care of the ball and took advantage of someone else's sloppiness. Plagued by turnovers in the early going this season, Arkansas (4-1) committed only 10 against the Hornets and overwhelmed Delaware State with an impressive full-court press in the second half. Roy Bright led the Hornets (2-3) with 28 points. Arkansas turned the ball over 32 times in a loss to Providence on Nov. 16. Welsh, a sophomore, has started both games at point guard since then. He had no turnovers in 25 minutes against Delaware State. Welsh also made all three of his 3-point attempts in the first half. The teams exchanged leads in the early going, but Arkansas closed with an 11-3 run for a 43-34 lead at halftime. The Razorbacks quickly broke the game open in the second half. Sonny Weems stole a pass along the baseline and in one motion tossed the ball back to Thomas for a layup and a 47-36 advantage. Later, the Razorbacks brought the crowd to its feet by forcing a 10-second violation. Townes then converted a 3-point play inside to make it 60-42 with 14:10 to play. Arkansas wasn't finished yet. Michael Washington stole an inbound pass and made a layup, then Weems added a steal along the right sideline and scored from the right wing. When Delaware State finally advanced the ball past midcourt, the Hornets rushed a quick shot, and that miss led to another 3-pointer by Welsh at the other end that made it 67-42. Delaware State, the regular-season champion in the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference last season, shot 53 percent but turned the ball over 21 times. Arkansas played the type of game new coach John Pelphrey advertised after taking over in April -- a return to the pressure defense the Razorbacks used when they reached great heights during the 1990s. Arkansas shot 57 percent from the field. Thomas was 6-for-6 and Townes went 7-for-9. Gary Ervin, the previous starting point guard, played 23 minutes. He finished with six points, six assists and no turnovers. Boss Hog, the Razorbacks' giant inflatable mascot, drew cheers early in the game when he held up a sign that said "LS-Who?" Arkansas beat No. 1 LSU in football Friday.
